repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Solution:
- Add `example_init.lua` and refer to it in `:h lua-guide-config`
- Refer to `lsp` in `:h nvim-quickstart`

I would like to give credit to [kickstart.nvim](https://github.com/nvim-lua/kickstart.nvim) for inspiration

Questions:
- Should I move lesson 7.2 to `nvim-quickstart`? The reason Vim puts it there (and before Lesson 7.3: Completion) is that Vim is in Vi-compatible mode by default, where many Vim features are disabled, including `cmdline-completion`. But if Vim detects a `vimrc` file, Vi-compatible will be disabled.
- Should there be an `example_init.vim`?
- Should I mention the plugin `nvim-lspconfig` in `lsp.txt`?

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body: @nenahp friendly warning: You've been leaving irrelevant comments on a number of issues over the last few days. Please refrain from doing so or you will get blocked from the Neovim org. We welcome contributions, but make sure they actually provide something valuable to the discussion instead of adding noise.
? most of the tutorial, afaik, is still mostly from the original
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,10 +129,6 @@ describe(':Tutor', function()
       {0:  }                                                                               |
       {0:  }If you prefer a book, {6:Practical Vim} by Drew Neil is recommended often          |
       {0:  }(the sequel, {6:Modern Vim}, includes material specific to Neovim).                |
-      {0:  }                                                                               |
-      {0:  }This tutorial was written by Michael C. Pierce and Robert K. Ware, Colorado    |
-      {0:  }School of Mines using ideas supplied by Charles Smith, Colorado State          |
-      {0:  }University. E-mail: {2:bware@mines.colorado.edu}.                                  |

comment_data.body: this performance note seems kind of "in the weeds", but if we're going to keep it, do we want to use an actual UIEnter handler instead of this accidental feature of `vim.schedule()` (which introduces bad/confusing habits, the opposite of what we want to do in this sample config)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+-- Set <space> as the leader key See `:help mapleader` NOTE: Must happen before plugins are loaded
+-- (otherwise wrong leader will be used)
+vim.g.mapleader = ' '
+
+-- [[ Setting options ]] See `:h vim.o`
+-- NOTE: You can change these options as you wish!
+-- For more options, you can see `:help option-list`
+-- To see documentation for an option, you can use `:h 'optionname'`, for example `:h 'number'`
+-- (Note the single quotes)
+
+-- Print the line number in front of each line
+vim.o.number = true
+
+-- Use relative line numbers, so that it is easier to jump with j, k. This will affect the 'number'
+-- option above, see `:h number_relativenumber`
+vim.o.relativenumber = true
+
+-- Sync clipboard between OS and Neovim. Schedule the setting after `UiEnter` because it can
+-- increase startup-time. (see `:h vim.schedule()`). Remove this option if you want your OS
+-- clipboard to remain independent. See `:help 'clipboard'`
+vim.schedule(function()

comment_data.body:
revert

and the "ide" note can go just below here.

comment_data.body:
probably want a one-liner codeblock to copy the config to the right location. similar to the steps from `:help nvim-from-vim`.

and this would probably go in `:help nvim-quickstart`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -93,10 +93,11 @@ Finally, you can include Lua code in a Vimscript file by putting it inside a
 Using Lua files on startup                                    *lua-guide-config*
 
 Nvim supports using `init.vim` or `init.lua` as the configuration file, but
-not both at the same time. This should be placed in your |config| directory,
-which is typically `~/.config/nvim` for Linux, BSD, or macOS, and
-`~/AppData/Local/nvim/` for Windows. Note that you can use Lua in `init.vim`
-and Vimscript in `init.lua`, which will be covered below.
+not both at the same time. This should be placed in your |config| directory
+(run `:echo stdpath('config')` to see where it is). Note that you can also use
+Lua in `init.vim` and Vimscript in `init.lua`, which will be covered below.
+
+Run `:e $VIMRUNTIME/example_init.lua` to see an example of a Lua config file.

comment_data.body: It's better to change the `969` below to `973`, as the email is also a link, while the "What's next" section doesn't contain any links.

comment_data.body: off topic: these should really be defaults
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,88 @@
+-- Set <space> as the leader key
+-- See `:help mapleader`
+-- NOTE: Must happen before plugins are loaded (otherwise wrong leader will be used)
+vim.g.mapleader = ' '
+
+-- [[ Setting options ]] See `:h vim.o`
+-- NOTE: You can change these options as you wish!
+-- For more options, you can see `:help option-list`
+-- To see documentation for an option, you can use `:h 'optionname'`, for example `:h 'number'`
+-- (Note the single quotes)
+
+-- Print the line number in front of each line
+vim.o.number = true
+
+-- Use relative line numbers, so that it is easier to jump with j, k. This will affect the 'number'
+-- option above, see `:h number_relativenumber`
+vim.o.relativenumber = true
+
+-- Sync clipboard between OS and Neovim. Schedule the setting after `UiEnter` because it can
+-- increase startup-time. Remove this option if you want your OS clipboard to remain independent.
+-- See `:help 'clipboard'`
+vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
+  callback = function()
+    vim.o.clipboard = 'unnamedplus'
+  end,
+})
+
+-- Case-insensitive searching UNLESS \C or one or more capital letters in the search term
+vim.o.ignorecase = true
+vim.o.smartcase = true
+
+-- Highlight the line where the cursor is on
+vim.o.cursorline = true
+
+-- Minimal number of screen lines to keep above and below the cursor.
+vim.o.scrolloff = 10
+
+-- Show <tab> and trailing spaces
+vim.o.list = true
+
+-- if performing an operation that would fail due to unsaved changes in the buffer (like `:q`),
+-- instead raise a dialog asking if you wish to save the current file(s) See `:help 'confirm'`
+vim.o.confirm = true
+
+-- [[ Set up keymaps ]] See `:h vim.keymap.set()`, `:h mapping`, `:h keycodes`
+
+-- Use <Esc> to exit terminal mode
+vim.keymap.set('t', '<Esc>', '<C-\\><C-n>')
+
+-- Map <A-j>, <A-k>, <A-h>, <A-l> to navigate between windows in any modes

comment_regular_data.body:
@justinmk Should I remove lesson 7.2 in tutor? The reason Vim puts it there (and before Lesson 7.3: Completion) is that Vim is in Vi-compatible mode by default, where many Vim features are disabled, including `cmdline-completion`. But if Vim detects a `vimrc` file, Vi-compatible will be disabled.

I also think it would be confusing if in tutor we tell them to create an `init.vim`, but in `nvim-quickstart` we tell them to create `init.lua`

> remove lesson 7.2 in tutor? The reason Vim puts it there (and before Lesson 7.3: Completion) is that Vim is in Vi-compatible mode by default

SGTM. Separate PR though
Should this be backported to Nvim 0.11?

Backport failed for `release-0.11`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.11
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-33524-to-release-0.11 origin/release-0.11
cd .worktree/backport-33524-to-release-0.11
git switch --create backport-33524-to-release-0.11
git cherry-pick -x 86b34ad073797da791348b97393d5d7b7ceca2e3
```

> It's an impossible project in some sense, because everyone has Strong Feelings about what it should be and they're often going in conflicting directions.

This is offtopic, but after reading some issue and PR comments in `kickstart.nvim`, I feel like some people confuse `kickstart.nvim` with a distro that users must regularly update (that's why some of them say things like changing this plugin will break users' habit). So I would suggest you to modify the README to tell users to copy relevant files to their config instead of forking the repo.

labels.description: Nvim defaults for options, colorscheme/theme, autocmds/events, etc.
labels.name: defaults

title: docs: make it more beginner-friendly
